awd_titl_txt: Fractional Viscoacoustic Wave Equations: Mathematical Analysis, Efficient Simulations, and Applications to Full-Waveform Inversion of Seismic Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Seismic waveform inversion is a widely used technique in the oil and gas industry as well as in geophysical research. This technique is among the most powerful subsurface imaging techniques; its success relies on both an accurate model of seismic wave propagation and efficient numerical computation for the practical implementation. This project addresses fundamental mathematical and computational issues in these two aspects and thus is of central importance for various applications, including imaging of the Earth's interior, subsurface exploration in the oil and gas industry, monitoring in carbon sequestration and geothermal facilities, and earthquake engineering. Students will be trained through involvement in the interdisciplinary research activities.

The main objectives of this research are to build mathematical and computational treatments for fractional viscoacoustic wave equations, to provide efficient and accurate modeling algorithms, and to further construct the viscoacoustic full-waveform inversion algorithm of seismic data. The fractional viscoacoustic wave equation, accounting for both seismic attenuation and dispersion in wave propagation, opens a promising direction to study seismic waves with attenuation. However, its nonlocality introduces considerable challenges. This project will involve systematic research in mathematical analysis, numerical simulations, and geophysical applications of data inversion, validation, and applications. On the theoretical side, the nonlocal properties of the fractional viscoacoustic wave equation will be investigated. On the numerical side, numerical analysis and efficient algorithms will be developed for its effective simulation. Building on these results, implementation issues for the viscoacoustic full-waveform inversion associated with fractional viscoacoustic wave equations will be addressed. The validation of the full-waveform inversion will be carried out with both synthetic data and field data from the Frio Formation carbon dioxide sequestration site in Texas.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Seismic exploration forms images of subsurface geology by detecting and sampling seismic waves. These images are widely used in oil-gas hydrocarbon exploration, geothermal exploration monitoring of CO2 injection, gas hydrated deposits in permafrost, and identification of potential nuclear waste repository sites. Current subsurface imaging techniques mainly include seismic reflection imaging, seismic tomography, and full-waveform inversion. Over the last decades, the advantages of full waveform inversion have made it one of the most powerful techniques for Earth imaging. The success of full-waveform inversion heavily relies on an accurate description of seismic wave propagation and efficient numerical solvers for the practical implementation. Furthermore, existing seismic imaging methods are implemented in the classical framework of elasticity, which mostly ignored the viscous (attenuation) property of the Earth's subsurface. The recently proposed fractional viscoacoustic wave equation has been able to account for both seismic attenuation and dispersion in wave propagation, opening up a promising direction for the study of seismic waves with attenuation. However, its nonlocality introduces considerable challenges.

The main objectives of this research are to build mathematical and computational treatments for the fractional viscoacoustic wave equation, to provide its efficient and accurate simulations, and to construct its full-waveform inversion algorithms of seismic data, so as to promote the subsurface seismic modeling and imaging techniques. The properties of the fractional Laplacian and its variations are investigated, with a key focus on developing the first numerical methods for the variable-order fractional Laplacian. Moreover, efficient and accurate numerical methods for fractional wave equations are also developed. On the other hand, data-driven surrogate models are built to address the computational and storage challenges posed by nonlocal problems. To further facilitate simulations in inversion, reduced-order modelings based on convolutional neural networks are developed for nonlocal models.

This project integrates analysis, simulations, and applications related to seismic data inversion. It not only fosters interdisciplinary research and bridges the gap between mathematics and geosciences but also advances the understanding and applications of full-waveform inversion. Our studies hold fundamental importance for various fields, such as imaging the Earth's interior, subsurface exploration in the oil and gas industry, monitoring CO2 sequestration and geothermal exploration, and earthquake engineering. This award has partially supported three PhD students, two of whom have already graduated. The support from NSF has also strengthened our PhD program and attracted more undergraduate and graduate students to pursue mathematics degrees. 

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2024
Modified by: Yanzhi Zhang
